Posts.Content: I also recommend a brain MRI.  I lost 60 pounds in 5 months.  Doc kept saying "try to eat." Just switched doctors, because I couldn't eat.  New doc ran brain mri, found mets to the brain and started treatment, now i'm eating 3 meals a day, walking again, haven't lost any more weight, feel much better, and hope to win this battle.  Don't wait for a doc who putzes around-you are your own best advocate! Cancer is aggressive-be agressive back!  Kick its bootie!
Posts.Title: symptoms of liver mets

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm stage iv breast cancer, 5 year survivor, and was in the ribbon trial using avastin and taxotere, but got too many side effects, so they switched to abraxane with avastin.  I have frequent nausea that doesn't let me eat, and have lost way too much weight.  Any ideas out there?  I have limited success from ginger tea and crackers, ativan works but knocks me out so that I'm not awake to eat, compazine doesn't work very well.  Walking around increases nausea dramatically.  I'm hopeful someone has other ideas.  Thanks, Starshine
Posts.Title: abraxane side affects

Posts.Content: On 8/22/2007 Georgiamom wrote: Hello,  I am in a trial with avastin and abraxane.  the avastin is an antiangiogenisis drug-works by inhibiting the tumors' ability to create it's circulatory system and feed itself.  I've had a few adverse affects-nose bleeds, lower energy, and regular injuries heal more slowly.  Otherwise, it has been very tolerable, and my cancer marcer was 900 a year ago, and is now 148.  I hope your mother does well-i've read that advanced age can be an advantage, because things don't progress as quickly-I hope that's true for her.   Starshine   My mom has started chemo and tomorrow will start Avastin along with Taxol.  She is 80 and I worry about the side effects with the Avastin.  Any information would be greatly appreciated.   Thank You
Posts.Title: Stage iv second time and 12 years later

Posts.Content: On 9/12/2007 jlbscreen wrote:   On 9/12/2007 jlbscreen wrote:   On 7/27/2007 Whitedory wrote: Hi,  I was treated with chemo the last time I was diagnosed and Arimidex afterwards.. Chemo and Armidex was working it killied the tumours so it seemed but another spot appeared on the lining of my lung so they put me on Avastin and Aromasin and I have been getting Avastin every two weeks since January of this year. I am due for new scans soon to see if it is working. Ask your doctor kudos to all who are going beyond conventional  medicine and LIVING with cancer.  I highly recommend the book "getting well again" by Karl simonton.  It changed my life, and is a short, easy read.  Starshine about Avastin treatment it is supposed to be a very good new drug. toMy daughter has stage 1V breast cancer after chemo, lumpectomy with 21 negative lymph nodes dissection and a 2-cm tumor removed.  ep-postive Her 2 receptor negative. She had radiation after.  She was cancer free for 3 years and then it was discovered as she was having tumor marker test every three months.  Since then, she has had the iv vitamin infusions, 3, in New Jersery and then we found a place here.  She has been taking it once a week.  In October, 2006, she entered into a trail with Abraxine and Avastin.  It was not know whether she was getting the avastin, but from her symptoms, we thought not.  She would have scans every six weeks.  Because of neuropoty in the feet, she recently elected to stop the abraxine and went out of the study.  Prior to that decision, she took 30 days off and went to Europe in which she had a great time.  I forgot to mention that she took tamoxifen for the three years up until the time she was diagnosed again.  It had awful side efects with extreme weight gain, depression, and nausea. I beleieve it did her system more harm than good.  This time she has changed her diet, but is still somewhat over weight.  She takes numerous vitamins.  She will be having scans again and they are trying to get her to take another drug that will supress harmones, but I am afraid that it will put her into the situation she had with tamoxefin.  The last scans she had, the nodes in her lungs, 4 of which had disappeared with the largest, almost gone.  I am so encouraged to hear how long you have lived because I believe that she can do it, but not with chemo and just conventional medicine.  No one seems to care what you eat, what your akline level is, nor anything even though they know that they only speak of months to live and not years with the treatment available. I am more the one that looks for everything and she is more the one to do as the doctor request.  Sometimes I make her mad and I admit to stepping over the line since it is her life.  On the first time around, I was not actively involved as she is independent, but this time, I feel it is our last chance and that you have to fight, study, believe, and be actiive in the choices that are available.      Kudos
Posts.Title: Stage iv second time and 12 years later

Posts.Content: On 7/25/2007 Whitedory wrote: Hi,   Is anyone out there who has survived this at stage IV for more than the statistical five years? I am about at the half way mark and I do not intend on checking out anytime soon. I would sure like everyone out there to know that you can survive this illness. I am  almost 12 years out of my first diagnosis which was stage two and then 9 years later stage IV and again 11 years alter again stage IV. Just let me know that you are there for those of us needing to know you can make it this far.  To all of you that tell us to get prepared!!!! Think again!!!! You get prepared!!!! HERE I AM!   BELIEVE IT !!!!!!!!!   hi, I'm so glad for you and encouraged to hear your news.  I got a diagnosis in 2002, found out it was stage iv in 2003, and have used a combo of western medicine and alternative medicine to stay as healthy and functional as possible.  Had a recent relapse, but things seem to be going in the right direction and I hope to return soon to work.  My mantras are live in the moment, and visualize your own reality.  I hope/plan to be around for a long time.   < : )  starshine
Posts.Title: Stage iv second time and 12 years later

Posts.Content: On 10/23/2007 kdmackey wrote: I have went through a long drawn out period of my life.  Two mouths to be exact.  That doesn't sound like a long time but it is when you find two lumps in your breast and you first see a doctor then you go for a Mammagram.  Then you have to wait for the results on that .  Then the doctor sends you to have a ultrasound and they do this on the wrong breast.  You go to the doctor again and he sends you back to do a ultra sound on the right breast.  Then you go back to the doctor to get the result on this breast. They tell me they found somthing that didn't look right so they need to do a biopsy.  They did this while I was awake which was very scary.  I had to wait a week, well I called the doctor to find out if the results was in and the nurse said "no one has called you to make an app. to come in, can you come in today at 3:30." I didn't have time to call my daughter, she lived 2hrs away and I couldn't get ahold of my boyfriend so I had to go by myself.  I was along when the doctor told me I had breast cancer.  I'm scared, I know theres a lot of women who have and are going through the same thing I am.  Just need to talk to someone and hear there story and experiences.  I think there should be faster ways to get things done so you don't have to wait so long to find out your results. 10-23-07 has changed my life.     Hi, KD,   This is Starshine-I'm just wondering how you are doing, and if your satisfied with the care you are getting now?  There are so many options and good treatments, I really hope you're on the right road!  I think of you and am send you all my best thoughts!  < : )  starshine
Posts.Title: today changed my life

Posts.Content: Hi, KD, I'm glad to hear you are getting a second opinion. It's a good thing to do as a general rule, but in your case, it sounds like your original health care providers are not on the ball-doing the wrong breast, not communicating with you, and not respecting your emotional needs as you move through your treatment. As Sherryingeorgia wrote to you, you should never go to an appointment alone; you need morale support, (we all do!) and you are in such shock and dismay that it's very easy to miss things the doctor says. I have a friend who goes to every appt. with me, takes notes in a notebook, and questions the doc about things I forget to ask. Before each appt. we make a list of concerns and questions, so that nothing is forgotten. And she's right there when I need a shoulder to cry on. At the same time I agree on getting a second opinion, try not to wait any longer than necessary to remove the cancer. You don't want to deal with it spreading, so the sooner you find a doc you trust and get started, the better your outcomes will be. I don't know what part of the country you're in, but in my area, The Cancer Center, City of Hope, UCLA Medical Center and Cancer Centers of America are the best places I know of-and they all treated me as a person with feelings and ideas, not just a body to deal with. Have you tried the Bernie Segal book? I really recommend it-a friend gave it to me, and for months I was too depressed to read anything about cancer. When I finally read it, it changed my whole attitude and the way I dealt with the cancer, and I wished I had read it sooner. It's full of stories of people who come out on top, with a lot of love, humor and compassion mixed in. You said your daughter is two hours away-do you have a friend who is closer who can be your buddy/advocate? And have you found a good counselor? I've been thinking of you a lot, and sending you healing thoughts. Let me know how you're doing, and I'm also here for you if there's any way my past experiences can help, or if you just want to talk. Your friend, Starshine
Posts.Title: today changed my life

Posts.Title: today changed my life

Posts.Content: Wow, you have certainly been through the wringer this last couple of months, and you aren't getting the support you need.  Believe me, there are many of us who have been through it and are surviving to tell about it and, hopefully, improve it. This isn't easy, but It doesn't all have to be that bad.  Sorry it's been so rough for you.  Cancer definitely changes your life-eventually, it can even make positive changes for you.  It's important to know that you are now engaged in a battle that many women have won-so make the decision to do everything possible to survive with them. A support group can really help-a cancer center or medical facility in your town shoul be able to put you in touch with one.  They aren't all the same, so if you don't care for a group after the first 2-3 times, try a different groups, until you find one where you are understood and supported.  Also, find a good counselor who's experienced with cancer issues.  When I got my diagnosis, I was in shock and denial, and for a while just drifted through treatment.  Then I read Peace, love and Healing (I think that's the title) by Bernie Siegal, and it made me do an about face.  I realized I'd been waiting around to die, instead of taking action to live.  I highly recommend the book. Finally, since I don't want to overwhelm you, be aware that there are lots of complementary treatments that help with side effects and increase positive outcomes of traditional medicine.  Reiki, herbs, meditation and visualization, and nutritional therapy have all helped me a lot.  Everyone's different, so try things out and see what helps you. You sound like a great person who's had an unusually rough time-I hope it gets better for you.  Write back and let me know how you're doing, starshine
Posts.Title: today changed my life
